name: Sagittarius A*
description: Sagittarius A* is a supermassive black hole at the Galactic Center of the Milky Way. It is a bright and very compact astronomical radio source. The formation of such supermassive black holes is still a topic of intense research.
funFacts: It spins at about 10% of the speed of light.
It flares up daily, emitting X-rays.
Stars orbit it at incredible speeds, like S2 which reaches 5,000 km/s.

name: M87*
description: The first black hole to be ever imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope. It resides at the center of the Messier 87 galaxy and shoots out a jet of plasma 5,000 light-years long.
funFacts: Its event horizon is larger than our entire solar system.
The image of its shadow confirmed Einstein's theory of general relativity.
It consumes 90 Earth masses of gas per day.

name: Einstein-Rosen Bridge
description: A wormhole is a speculative structure linking disparate points in spacetime. Einstein and Rosen discovered this solution in 1935. While consistent with general relativity, no observational evidence for them exists yet.
funFacts: Would require 'exotic matter' with negative energy density to stay open.
Could theoretically allow for time travel as well as space travel.
Interstellar movie featured a scientifically plotted representation of one.

name: White Hole
description: A theoretical time-reversed black hole. While a black hole lets nothing escape, a white hole lets nothing enter. It ejects matter and light but cannot be entered from the outside.
funFacts: No white holes have ever been observed.
Some theories suggest the Big Bang itself was a white hole.
They are mathematically valid solutions to Einstein's field equations.

name: PSR B1257+12 (Lich)
description: A millisecond pulsar located 2,300 light-years away in the constellation Virgo. It hosts the first exoplanets ever discovered, known as 'draugr', 'poltergeist', and 'phobetor'.
funFacts: The planets orbiting it are bathed in deadly radiation.
It is a 'zombie star' - a core remnant of a massive supernova.

name: SGR 1806-20
description: A type of neutron star with an extremely powerful magnetic field. SGR 1806-20 has a magnetic field quadrillions of times stronger than Earth's.
funFacts: A flare from this star in 2004 released more energy in 0.2 seconds than the Sun does in 250,000 years.
Its magnetic field is strong enough to wipe credit cards from the Moon.
Starquakes on magnetars cause massive gamma-ray bursts.
